contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox UK place |country = England |official_name= Thrapston |latitude= 52.394 |longitude= -0.535 |civil_parish= | population = 4,835 | population_ref = ([[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 Census]]) |shire_district= [[East Northamptonshire]] |shire_county= [[Northamptonshire]] |region= East Midlands |constituency_westminster= [[Corby (UK Parliament constituency)|Corby]] |post_town= KETTERING |postcode_district = NN14 |postcode_area= NN |dial_code= 01832 |os_grid_reference= SP997784 }} '''Thrapston''' is a small town in [[Northamptonshire]], England. It is the headquarters of the [[East Northamptonshire]] district, and in 2001 had a population of 4,855. By 2006, this was estimated to be over 5,700.<ref>[http://www.east-northamptonshire.gov.uk/pp/service/detail.asp?id=2541 East Northamptonshire District Council]</ref> [[Image:UK Thrapston.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Sign in Thrapston]] Thrapston is close to the [[River Nene]] and is at the junction of the [[A14 (Britain)|A14]] and the [[A45 road|A45]]. Until the 1960s, Thrapston had two railway stations. Thrapston (Midland) was on the [[Kettering]] to [[Cambridge]] route, and the former station and viaduct can be seen from the adjacent A14 road. Thrapston (Bridge Street) was on the former [[London and North Western Railway|LNWR]] [[Northampton]] to [[Peterborough]] line. The market charter was granted over 800 years ago, in the year 1205, in exchange for two [[palfrey]]s. This is celebrated every year with the town's [[Charter fair]], where the high street is closed and the people in the town get together to commemorate this event. A relative of [[George Washington]], Sir John Washington, lived in Chancery Lane in the town, and his wife is buried in the church. Sir John was brother to George Washington's great-grandfather. Naturalist and writer [[Horace William Wheelwright]] practiced as an attorney in Thrapston in the 1840s. Fashion photographer [[James Kenny (photographer)|James Kenny]] currently lives in the town. Thrapston has two schools, Thrapston [[primary education|Primary]]<ref>[http://www.thrapston-primary.northants.sch.uk/ Thrapston Primary School]</ref> and King John middle school,<ref>[http://www.kingjohn.northants.sch.uk/ King John Middle School]</ref> which together serve children from four to thirteen. Thrapston Primary is for children aged 4 to 9 and King John is for ages 9 to 13, following which children go to schools elsewhere, usually [[Prince William School]] in [[Oundle]]. The town's football club, [[Thrapston Town F.C.|Thrapston Town]], plays in the [[United Counties Football League|United Counties League]]. The local authorities that cover different aspects of civic life in Thrapston are Thrapston Town Council, East Northamptonshire Council, and Northamptonshire County Council. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category inline|Thrapston}} *[http://www.thrapstononline.co.uk Thrapston OnLine] {{Northamptonshire}} {{River Nene}} {{Northamptonshire-geo-stub}} [[Category:Towns in Northamptonshire]] [[Category:Charter fairs]]
